<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 462, 88]]<|/det|>
A student measures the volume of a cork.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
He puts some water into a measuring cylinder and then one glass ball. He puts the cork and then a second, identical glass ball into the water as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 809, 472]]<|/det|>
Diagram 3 shows the water level after the cork and the second glass ball are added.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 381, 502]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the cork?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 870, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an air-filled rubber toy. A child sits on the toy and its volume decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 561, 120]]<|/det|> The temperature of the air in the toy does not change. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 128, 695, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 276, 567, 294]]<|/det|> How does the air pressure in the toy change and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 707, 435]]<|/det|>
pressurereason

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 462, 106, 480]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 920, 495]]<|/det|> A strip of iron and a strip of brass are firmly attached to each other along their entire length. This combination is a bimetallic strip. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 504, 660, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 551, 622]]<|/det|> This bimetallic strip is heated and it bends as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 631, 727, 732]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 742, 630, 759]]<|/det|> The bimetallic strip is now cooled and becomes straight again. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 772, 599, 789]]<|/det|> What causes the bimetallic strip to become straight again? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 800, 134, 819]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 800, 479, 819]]<|/det|> The brass contracts more than the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 134, 846]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 828, 475, 846]]<|/det|> The brass expands more than the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 855, 131, 873]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 855, 479, 873]]<|/det|> The iron contracts more than the brass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 881, 133, 899]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 881, 475, 899]]<|/det|> The iron expands more than the brass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an electric heater being used to heat a beaker of water and an identical beaker containing oil. Both are heated for one minute.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 112, 675, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 255, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the water and the temperature of the oil increase steadily. The increase in temperature of the oil is much greater than that of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 220, 320]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 485, 349]]<|/det|>
Oil has a higher boiling point than water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 133, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 357, 477, 375]]<|/det|>
Oil has a lower boiling point than water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 131, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 383, 581, 401]]<|/det|>
The oil has a larger thermal capacity than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 409, 133, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 409, 593, 427]]<|/det|>
The oil has a smaller thermal capacity than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 454, 106, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 477, 472]]<|/det|>
The air temperature in a cold room is \(15^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 630, 503]]<|/det|>
A heater that contains water at \(50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) is used to heat the room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 861, 533]]<|/det|>
By which process is most of the thermal energy transferred throughout the air in the room?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 543, 133, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 543, 245, 561]]<|/det|>
conduction

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 570, 133, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 570, 245, 588]]<|/det|>
convection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 597, 133, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 597, 253, 615]]<|/det|>
evaporation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 623, 133, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 623, 228, 640]]<|/det|>
radiation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 666, 104, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 666, 566, 685]]<|/det|>
Which statement about convection currents is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 133, 713]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 694, 910, 712]]<|/det|>
Convection currents occur because, when cooled, liquids contract and become more dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 720, 131, 739]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 720, 915, 739]]<|/det|>
Convection currents occur because, when warmed, liquids expand and become more dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 747, 131, 765]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 747, 492, 765]]<|/det|>
Convection currents only occur in liquids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 774, 133, 792]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 774, 581, 792]]<|/det|>
Convection currents only occur in solids and liquids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 573, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram represents a wave travelling along a rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 611, 120]]<|/det|>
Which labelled arrow indicates the wavelength of the wave?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 127, 715, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 323, 104, 342]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 841, 343]]<|/det|>
The diagram represents plane wavefronts of a water wave about to strike a solid barrier.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[363, 348, 628, 476]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 792, 505]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the position of the wavefronts after reflection at the barrier?

<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an object in front of a plane mirror. A ray of light from the object is incident on the mirror. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 112, 611, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 920, 317]]<|/det|> Through which point does the reflected ray pass, and at which point is the image of the object formed? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 571, 472]]<|/det|>
point through which reflected ray passespoint at which image is formed
APR
BPS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 107, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 828, 520]]<|/det|> Which ray diagram shows a converging lens forming a real image of a small object O? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 533, 850, 887]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 853, 89]]<|/det|>
Visible light, X-rays and microwaves are all components of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 489, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the waves is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 868, 147]]<|/det|>
In a vacuum, microwaves travel faster than visible light and have a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 920, 190]]<|/det|>
In a vacuum, microwaves travel at the same speed as visible light and have a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 197, 131, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 196, 824, 215]]<|/det|>
In a vacuum, X-rays travel faster than visible light and have a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 133, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 222, 912, 240]]<|/det|>
In a vacuum, X-rays travel at the same speed as visible light and have a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 107, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 267, 813, 286]]<|/det|>
Space is a vacuum. Waves from stars are used to reveal information about the stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 609, 315]]<|/det|>
Which type of waves do **not** reveal information about stars?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 325, 128, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 325, 227, 344]]<|/det|>
infra-red

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 128, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 352, 255, 369]]<|/det|>
radio waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 128, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 378, 245, 395]]<|/det|>
ultrasound

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 405, 128, 424]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 405, 205, 422]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 450, 107, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
A student stands \(180 \text{m}\) in front of a vertical, flat cliff and bangs together two pieces of wood to make a short, loud sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 912, 512]]<|/det|>
A timer records the echo of the sound 1.5 seconds after the pieces of wood are banged together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 524, 542]]<|/det|>
Based on this result, what is the speed of sound?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 552, 133, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 552, 225, 570]]<|/det|>
120 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 552, 298, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 552, 393, 570]]<|/det|>
240 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 552, 470, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 552, 561, 570]]<|/det|>
270 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 552, 640, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 552, 727, 570]]<|/det|>
540 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 597, 107, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 597, 707, 616]]<|/det|>
A train of steel nails and a train of iron nails hang from a strong magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 625, 692, 730]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 737, 571, 755]]<|/det|>
The trains are then carefully removed from the magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 351, 785]]<|/det|>
What happens to the trains?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 796, 131, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 796, 324, 814]]<|/det|>
Both trains fall apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 823, 131, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 823, 361, 841]]<|/det|>
Both trains stay together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 850, 131, 867]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 850, 455, 867]]<|/det|>
Only the train of iron nails falls apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 876, 131, 894]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 876, 463, 893]]<|/det|>
Only the train of steel nails falls apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The north pole of a bar magnet is placed in turn next to each end of a rod X. One end of the rod moves away from the north pole but the other end moves towards the north pole. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 922, 149]]<|/det|> The experiment is repeated with the bar magnet and a different rod Y but this time both ends of the rod move towards the north pole. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 576, 179]]<|/det|> From which materials could the rods X and Y be made? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 418, 319]]<|/det|>
rod Xrod Y
Asoft ironcopper
Bsoft ironsoft iron
Csteelcopper
Dsteelsoft iron
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 348, 104, 365]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 745, 365]]<|/det|> A student investigates the electrostatic charges on three objects P, Q and R. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 378, 920, 410]]<|/det|> The student places object P on the insulated pan of a balance and notes the reading on the balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 920, 455]]<|/det|> The student then holds object Q a small distance above object P and notes the reading on the balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 920, 501]]<|/det|> Finally, the student holds object R the small distance above object P and notes the reading on the balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 437, 530]]<|/det|> The student's observations are shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 537, 866, 680]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 670, 705]]<|/det|> Which row gives possible charges that explain these observations? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 717, 609, 845]]<|/det|>
charge on Pcharge on Qcharge on R
Anegativepositivenegative
Bnegativenegativenegative
Cpositivepositivenegative
Dpositivenegativepositive

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 510, 89]]<|/det|>
Which equation is used to calculate resistance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 118]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 100, 371, 118]]<|/det|>
resistance = p.d. + current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 125, 371, 144]]<|/det|>
resistance = p.d. – current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 152, 371, 170]]<|/det|>
resistance = p.d. \(\times\) current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 180, 133, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 180, 371, 197]]<|/det|>
resistance = p.d. \(\div\) current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 224, 104, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 223, 724, 243]]<|/det|>
A student connects a circuit with a power supply, a lamp and an ammeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 457, 272]]<|/det|>
Where must the ammeter be connected?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 134, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 282, 604, 301]]<|/det|>
in parallel with the lamp to measure current in the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 134, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 308, 744, 327]]<|/det|>
in parallel with the lamp to measure potential difference across the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 134, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 335, 594, 353]]<|/det|>
in series with the lamp to measure current in the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 133, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 361, 734, 380]]<|/det|>
in series with the lamp to measure potential difference across the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 407, 106, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 490, 425]]<|/det|>
Two \(3.0 \Omega\) resistors are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 616, 455]]<|/det|>
Which statement about their combined resistance is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 133, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 466, 512, 484]]<|/det|>
The combined resistance is less than \(3.0 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 494, 432, 512]]<|/det|>
The combined resistance is \(3.0 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 131, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 522, 680, 540]]<|/det|>
The combined resistance is more than \(3.0 \Omega\) but less than \(6.0 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 550, 133, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 549, 432, 567]]<|/det|>
The combined resistance is \(6.0 \Omega\).

Its circuit also contains a switch and a fuse. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 532, 546, 549]]<|/det|> Which circuit shows the fuse in the correct position? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 556, 915, 866]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> There is an electric current in a straight wire in the direction into the page. This produces a magnetic field around the wire. All the field lines are circles but only one field line is shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 112, 655, 250]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 260, 452, 279]]<|/det|> Which row describes the magnetic field? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 635, 497]]<|/det|>
direction of the field linesspacing of the field lines

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 526, 106, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|> A wire carrying a current is placed in a magnetic field. The wire experiences a force due to the field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 571, 586, 590]]<|/det|> Which action does **not** change the direction of the force? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 599, 133, 617]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 598, 617]]<|/det|> increasing the current and reversing the field direction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 133, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 625, 630, 644]]<|/det|> increasing the current, keeping the field direction constant <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 133, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 653, 598, 670]]<|/det|> reversing the current and increasing the field strength <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 678, 133, 696]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 678, 623, 696]]<|/det|> reversing the current, keeping the field direction constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 650, 92]]<|/det|> Different isotopes of chlorine are represented as \(^{35}_{17}\mathrm{Cl}\) and \(^{37}_{17}\mathrm{Cl}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 443, 126]]<|/det|> They behave the same way chemically. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 138, 220, 156]]<|/det|> Why is this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 166, 134, 184]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 166, 462, 184]]<|/det|> They have the same nuclide notation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 193, 134, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 191, 494, 210]]<|/det|> They have the same number of neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 218, 134, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 217, 494, 236]]<|/det|> They have the same number of nucleons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 244, 134, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 244, 484, 262]]<|/det|> They have the same number of protons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 288, 106, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 630, 306]]<|/det|> A radioactive source emits three types of radiation R, S and T. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 318, 866, 336]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an experiment set up to study the penetrating properties of R, S and T. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 344, 707, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 455, 523]]<|/det|> Which types of radiation are R, S and T? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 533, 672, 662]]<|/det|>
RST
Aα-particlesβ-particlesγ-rays
Bα-particlesγ-raysβ-particles
Cβ-particlesα-particlesγ-rays
Dγ-raysβ-particlesα-particles
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 689, 106, 707]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 689, 566, 707]]<|/det|> What is meant by the _half-life_ of a radioactive isotope? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 718, 134, 736]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 718, 625, 736]]<|/det|> half of the time taken for all of the original nuclei to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 134, 762]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 744, 581, 762]]<|/det|> the time taken for half of the original nuclei to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 771, 134, 789]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 771, 604, 789]]<|/det|> the time taken for the charges on all the nuclei to halve <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 134, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 797, 584, 816]]<|/det|> the time taken for the mass of each nucleus to halve
